awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Reactive Cyclic Induction Marine Diesel Emissions Reduction Monitoring and Delivery System Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the potential reduction of toxic nitrogen oxides (NOx) and harmful carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from marine diesel engines. There are approximately 4 million diesel-powered craft in use globally, emitting approximately one billion tons of CO2 and 100 million tons of NOx annually. This project seeks to remove at least 80% of the NOx and 30% of the CO2 from marine diesel exhaust, contributing to a reduction in both greenhouse gas emissions and in air pollution that creates health hazards in coastal cities. There is no alternative, commercially-viable product that reduces CO2 and NOx emissions from marine diesel engines. The proposed concept seeks to overcome the disadvantages of competing technologies that are unworkable due to heat and space restraints in a confined boat engine room. The project may enable boat manufacturers to meet new international maritime regulations on engine emissions and may contribute new knowledge related to the engineering of monitoring and delivery systems for marine and land/vehicle emissions reduction systems. In addition to environmental benefits, the technology meets a global commercial demand and creates good paying jobs for an export-oriented US industry.

The goal of this project is to develop a low thermal electro-emulsification solution to reduce emissions in marine diesel exhaust, specifically nitrogen oxides (NOx) by 80% to meet the new International Maritime Organization (IMO) regulations and carbon dioxide (CO2) by 30%. The technology will be incorporated into a fuel processing system that can be integrated into existing diesel engines on marine boats. This system will precisely inject reaction-altering chemicals at the proper time in the combustion cycle to reach the desired reduction of CO2 and NOx. The system will also monitor the exhaust stream to ensure no harmful byproducts are discharged into the marine environment. This work will further develop the understanding of diesel emissions reduction and may be transferable to other vehicle and land-based applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Phase 1 grant #2208348 project outcome for Walter Schulz, Principal Investigator (PI) and Stec Technology, Inc (Stec) during the development of a monitoring and delivery system (M/DS) for Stec’s Reactive Cyclic Induction (RCI) system has been the successful advancement of how to build a commercially viable unit that can reduce the levels of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon dioxide (CO2) in marine diesel exhaust emissions.   

Emissions from the diesel engines of boats and ships contain highly toxic gases like NOx and greenhouse gases like CO2 that are an increasingly significant source of the world’s atmospheric pollution.  The unique dynamics and high-power requirements of marine craft make electric propulsion as currently configured for other transportation sectors not a viable alternative.  There currently is no satisfactory technology available for use on marine craft to reduce NOx and CO2 because of the unique characteristics of confined marine engine rooms. The specific objective of the RCI system with M/DS component has been to produce an alternative to Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) which is the only other NOx reduction exhaust system that is currently available world-wide. SCR was developed for land-based diesel engines, specifically cars and trucks. Realizing the significant health hazards of exposure to NOx, government regulations world-wide mandated reducing NOx emissions from land-based diesel engines about 15 years ago, followed by similar regulations for marine diesel engines about 3 years ago. The SCR NOx diesel exhaust reduction system is based on injecting urea-based diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) at extremely high temperatures in excess of 800F/420C into the exhaust stream to achieve a chemical reaction that reduces NOx into the begin components of nitrogen and oxygen.  While SCR works in open air applications like a diesel-powered tractor trailer truck travelling down a highway at 65 MPH this high heat component makes SCR totally unsuitable in the confined engine room of every commercial marine craft. Other problems with SCR units are cost (50% of the cost of a marine diesel engine), size (40% of the size and weight of a marine diesel engine), no CO2 reduction, and SCR units must be included at the time a marine diesel engine is manufactured so they are not retrofittable.  To bring current marine craft into compliance with future emissions regulations by using SCR units would require ripping out all existing marine engines and dramatically increasing the size and ventilation of existing engine rooms, an economic impossibility for most boat owners.

Stec’s RCI unit replaces a boat’s existing exhaust system so no engine room modifications are necessary, adds no heat, will cost about 10% of the cost of a marine diesel engine, and reduces CO2 by 20%.  RCI technology is based on extensive on-going university research that shows that seawater along with other chemicals introduced into an electro-emulsification chamber will reduce the NOx and CO2 in marine diesel exhaust emissions by 80% and 20% respectively.  While working on developing the MDS component of RCI a series of unanticipated development problems with RCI unit were encountered in the emulsifying helix chamber which had to be reconfigured. It was found that the hydrated calcium and other elements had to be replaced by low temperature (80°F /27 C) DEF. In manually monitored testing the modified RCI system showed 80% average NOx reductions and about 20% CO2 reduction. However, the complexity of the reconfiguration did delay work on the M/DS component which required significant modification. The changes in the RCI unit did not affect the US/international patent coverage on the RCI exhaust system.

The unique characteristics of the RCI reactive cyclical induction process enabled the DEF in combination with sodium hydroxide and salt water to produce the desired reaction without the requirement of excessive heat, plus eliminated the requirement of using calcium as an additive, which had complicated the development of the M/DS as liquified calcium was difficult to control.  DEF also helped to neutralize acidity produced during the process so that the monitored discharge from the RCI system was harmless.  

In conclusion, PI Schulz and Stec's team achieved the goal of constructing a smaller commercially viable RCI unit that reduced NOx and CO2 in marine diesel exhaust by the targets of 80% and 20% respectively based on extensive tests on our 32’ test boat with a 265hp Cummins 5.9L marine diesel engine operated out of New Bedford, MA during 2023. We enhanced our understanding of the diesel exhaust emissions reduction process significantly by using readily available and easy-to-use DEF as an additional chemical component of our treatment process. At the same time, we produced a proto-type functioning M/DS unit that will require further development to incorporate as part of the new and improved RCI system.  Installation of RCI units on marine craft worldwide will benefit the environment and mankind's health and well-being on many levels.
